intro: Alsodeia hispida, commonly known as the hairy alsike, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes many other well-known flowering plants. The plant is characterized by its hairy stems and leaves, which give it its common name. It produces small, yellow flowers arranged in racemes, typically blooming in the spring. Alsodeia hispida is often found in meadows and disturbed soils, and it serves as a food source for various pollinators.
